title: Question 11
prompt: <u>The car was making an unusual noise.  The car needed a new engine. </u>
description: Read the underlined sentences.  Then choose the sentence that best combines those sentences into one.
feedback:
The best response joins the two sentences with the word “because.” This word shows the relationship between the two sentences. Since the dependent clause “because it needed a new engine” is at the end of the sentence, no comma is needed before the clause.

The sentence “The car was making an unusual noise the new engine was the reason” is a run-on. The two sentences can’t be joined with no punctuation or conjunctions.

The sentence “It needed, a new engine because of the unusual noise” is missing the word “car.” It also has an unnecessary comma after the verb “needed.”

The sentence “The car was making an unusual noise consequently it needed a new engine” uses the word “consequently” to join the sentences. A word like “consequently,” “therefore,” or “however” can be used as a transition, but the sentences need to be joined with a semicolon. The transition word should have a comma after it, like this: “The car was making an unusual noise; consequently, it needed a new engine.”
